Have you had one of these from GOV.uk?

It seems Cyber criminals don‚Äôt care about shafting people in the middle of a global pandemic.

Millions of emails are being sent each day pretending to be legitimate authorities, but are in fact hackers trying to confuse people.

The vast majority of people can recognise them but some get taken in and hand over sensitive information or give people an entry point into a business‚Äô infrastructure.

Most companies offer training for staff to recognise these, but so many still fail to follow all the steps of verification of the legitimacy of emails.

It can be quite scary to think that the security of your business could be resting on how well a member of staff follows the training in recognising bogus emails.

Do you want to be a Chief People Officer?! Then the GROW program is for you!

Brought to you in partnership with Enrique Rubio & the team at Hacking HR, GROW is a program for the next generation of people leaders.

Our first cohort is already underway!

The second cohort begins in June & features the following topics:

* Personal Branding
* Business & HR Strategy
* People Science
* Organizational Design
* Talent Strategy
* Employee Experience
* Work Technology
* Service Delivery (HR Operations)
* Analytics & Data
* Diversity, Equity, Inclusion & Belonging
* Employment Branding & Communications
* Personal Leadership

**

The GROW program is designed for the next generation of CHROs & costs $2,499 USD. 

The GROWx program was designed for the next generation of HRDs / HRVPs & costs $1,499 USD.

I‚Äôll link additional details in the comments below.

The power of community learning is amplified through inclusion.

We hope to see you there!

Spring tends to be my busiest season as a 
hashtag
#speaker ‚Äî but 
hashtag
#coronavirus had other plans this year. Almost 20 events have been canceled or postponed for me.

I can honestly say I‚Äôm not complaining. This is part of the gift of life, so I‚Äôm focusing on living E+R=O and asking myself ‚Äúwhat does this make possible.‚Äù In fact, business is healthy and I‚Äôm excited about the future.

But, as spring turns into summer and I look back over the past 3 months, I do want to take a moment and admit that I miss all the people I would have met and all the place I would visited 
hashtag
#speaking . I believe it‚Äôs healthy to mourn loss, and this morning is that season for me.

We are recruiting an experienced Human Resources Generalist for a cutting edge technology company in the Sacramento area. This is an exciting direct hire opportunity to bring your career to the next level! 

In this role you will manage the day-to-day human resources operations of the HR department. Ideal candidates are able to assist with recruitment, worksite safety, policy writing, employee relations and training and development. This position requires an extremely perceptive person who can relate to individuals at all levels within the organization.

Are you a learner?

This pandemic has a global impact and an unknown duration. No organization is an expert in pandemic response, and employees can provide information on situations that HR may not have anticipated. 

McLean & Company‚Äôs Pandemic Engagement Pulse Check allows organizations to gather feedback from employees to ensure that they're responding in a meaningful way. Here‚Äôs how:

- Assess engagement levels across the organization and by key demographics.
- Dive deeper into COVID-19-specific challenges and open-ended questions.
- Discover high-performing areas and opportunities for improvement.
- Diagnose and create action plans for specific areas of focus.
- Launch, collect data and debrief results quickly.

Link: https://lnkd.in/dn2KQBE

While we celebrate unboxing at our new office, Twitter celebrates its vision of an ‚Äúofficeless‚Äù workforce, distributed around the globe.

If there are no longer traditional offices in the future, what will team spirit sound like? How will a change program spread and be adopted? What will be left of corporate culture? How will you interpret body language? What will be left of your instinct if video-chat is the new normal? What will onboarding feel like from your couch or kitchen table?

How to Manage Covid Burnout
-  Openly talk with your manager about how you are feeling
-  Seek help in prioritising and delegating
-  Manage your stakeholders expectations
- "We are all in this together" - yeah this one is cliche and at times I am sick of hearing it, but its true. Talking openly with friends, manager, colleagues etc helps us all deal with any insecurities, stress and lack of control we have all felt through this.

After completing the 2 year - Part time track at USC MS in Human Resource Management, it was my dream for my 4 year old son Atticus, to see me walk across that prestigious stage this Friday. The road to get there was quite bumpy and I wavered a bit, but thankfully I had tons of support from friends, family and amazing colleagues to help me get to the finish line. I'm proud to be first generation Latinx and the first in the Hernandez family to receive a Master's degree! With this great accomplishment I can show my son, that any goal you set for yourself, is indeed within reach and possible!  

As we all adapt to world we are currently living in, Atticus will now sit alongside me and celebrate with my fellow classmates via Zoom!

‚ÄòBecause you are awesome‚Äô

This is the message I received from my Managing Director Geoff Crews and fellow Directors of Forsythes Recruitment & HR today. Between now and end of June each and every employee is entitled and encouraged to take 3 x ‚Äòbecause I‚Äôm awesome‚Äô leave days - no explanation needed. 

What a way to boost staff morale, culture and productivity when your hard work is recognised, especially in difficult times like these. 

I have always been a big believer in this quote from Sir Richard Branson and today Forsythes Recruitment & HR nailed it. The (virtual) reaction and energy this generosity has generated is electric and inspiring!

I am privileged to work for such an awesome company, I encourage more to jump on the bandwagon!

EMOTIONS WILL BE HIGH AND THAT‚ÄôS OK ‚Äì Many will have had more time than they really wanted, to reflect, soul search and rediscover ‚Äì HOWEVER JUST BEFORE YOU DO RESIGN on the first day in the office;

1. Go back and reflect on the reasons why you joined the Company in the first place, is that all gone, or is there something worth staying for?

2. Explore all internal options; there will be new structures and operating plans coming, will it be possible to move to a new role or a new team.

3. If salary and benefits are a concern have these discussions with your manager; if not successful your manager's manager ‚Äì get a definitive answer.

4. If career opportunities and development appear to be currently lacking, speak with your manager and HR.

5. Talk to friends and colleagues outside the Company; REMEMBER NO MATTER HOW GREEN THE GRASS MAY LOOK; YOU STILL WILL HAVE TO CUT IT!

6. If you are still resigning, ensure you have a plan; evaluate the market, what's the true value and need for your skills and experience.

Most important, never leave your Company if the reason is who you are reporting to ‚Äì ‚ÄúNothing stays the same forever.‚Äù 

Make sound practical reasons when writing ‚ÄòTHIS IS MY NOTICE PERIOD‚Äô letter.

Today organizations are trying to develop a growth mindset in employees.

Having a Growth mindset has many benefits not just at organization level but also at a personal level, including greater comfort with taking personal risks and striving for stretched goals; higher motivation; enhanced brain development across wider ranges of tasks; lower stress, anxiety and depression; better work relationships; and higher performance levels.

I came across this Beautifully explained video on Growth mindset where Professor Carol Dweck talks about her groundbreaking work on developing mind-sets. She emphasizes the power of "yet" in helping students succeed in and out of the classroom.

So are you nurturing a growth mindset in your employees?

Google's and Facebook's employees will work remotely until 2021

These two companies alone have 165,000 employees.

We already know that other large companies are adopting the same policy.

How is this decision going to affect the economy?

Just think about office spaces, taxis, restaurants, coffee shops, office supplies, near-work shopping, etc.

If the stay-at-home employees are not going to consume these services, the outcome for the employees of these services is clear.

I feel it‚Äôs working against the reopening of our economy.

And if it hurts the economy, eventually it will hurt the companies that leave their employees at home.

Any thoughts about what‚Äôs stand behind this decision?

Connect with me.

How much can change in one year?

Today, I celebrated one-year at BeniComp Health Solutions and it has been a year full of moments.

What moments have you had?

As a person born with a physical disability I understand first-hand how difficult accessing and affording healthcare is. I am motivated each day to remove the barriers to high quality and affordable care because the work I do impacts people and their livelihoods.

From being recognized as a Rising Star to speaking on a panel on how we can tailor health plans to meet the needs of the multi-generational workforce it has been a rewarding journey.

It‚Äôs not just about claims and deductibles, it‚Äôs about the person knowing they can get quality care at an affordable price.

Dennis a partner in the trenches who has been a champion for employers.

Dan a fellow innovator and brilliant mind.

Laura-Beth and Nick driven beyond belief.

Nancy a passionate voice for implementing health-enhancing infrastructure.

Sharon it is all about putting people first and wowing them.

Honored to know broker of the year finalists Ben and Derek.

Mark a change-agent who has transformed my life.

Kevin shows how we can influence positive and meaningful change.

David & Emma mentors and close friends.

Do YOU have a PLAN B for your CAREER?





If you‚Äôre in IT, you‚Äôre in really good shape.

Because your skills transfer to multiple industries.

But your ‚Äúideal position‚Äù may not be something you have right now ‚Ä¶ 

Then what? 

Plan B - Got one? 

That might look like your main position is on hold ‚Ä¶ 

But to do interim consulting remotely for now. 

Times during COVID19 are unprecedented, 

So no one knows how this plays out. 

Companies may fail ‚Ä¶ 

You could be laid off ‚Ä¶ 

Hiring processes have already paused for many companies ‚Ä¶ 

But one thing we know is this.

If the current jobs don‚Äôt stay in place,  new jobs will be created.

Many of those will most likely be virtual and contract positions.

Remote work options will increase, and we all know IT is going to be in massive demand.

So your responsibility is this ‚Üí BE PREPARED. 

I‚Äôll post again about Linkedin profile optimization. 

That‚Äôs the first place you can start. 

More hiring managers and recruiters are on Linkedin today than ever. 

Get out there. 

Stay healthy ;)

To all HRs, with love, from every professional ever:

-If you're not hiring, please remove any open positions from all job portals

-If you can't afford to onboard a new employee, let them know. Don't indefinitely defer their joining for nothing

-If a candidate is no longer in the running, let them know

-If you know you might be looking at laying people off in the times to come, communicate to them in time

-If someone completes an assignment as a part of the selection process, give them feedback. Don't let these creative people think their intellectual property was misused

-If you don't have the budget (+/- 10%), don't initiate the process. Don't put a candidate through so much only to put a shocking figure at the end

-If someone reaches out to you, be kind enough to acknowledge

-And lastly, if you want the industry to look up to your culture, preach it every step of the way. And yes, that includes treating potentially future employees with respect as well.

The above list is the result of innumerous stories from multiple people in my network. You have a massive responsibility, being the face of your company, dear HRs. Don't mess it up :)

2017 article from my Human Capital Management class ringing true today - especially in the midst of economic uncertainty and organizations considering workforce redeployment:

"With companies expecting increasing flexibility and agility from their staff, a key aspect of maintaining relationships is that the psychological contract is upheld. The very need for adaptability may run counter to how things have been done before, and so changes in the needs of the company may be perceived as breaches of the contract. Proactively managing employees‚Äô expectations therefore becomes an ongoing and necessary process."

üööUnited Parcel Service is the world‚Äôs largest package shipping company, so saving a tiny bit of gasoline on every truck route can generate enormous savings, both in expenses and in impact on the 
hashtag
#environment. For example, reducing each route by one mile per day for a year can save the company $50 million. Thus, efficiency is a major factor in work design. 

üîéRecently, the company began using a system called ORION (for On-Road Integrated Optimization and Navigation) for its 55,000 drivers in the United States. The Orion system gathers data from customers, vehicles, and drivers‚Äô handheld computers. It analyzes the 
hashtag
#data ‚Äîeven times for pickup and delivery when customers have special requests‚Äî and designs routes for each driver to use the minimum time and fuel, driving the minimum distance.

üìàAccording to UPS, ORION is expected to save the company $300 to $400 million a year. With results like these, it is easy to see why UPS invested years to develop this system. The challenge for 
hashtag
#HR managers is to find drivers who are willing to commit to a system in which their every turn is planned by a computer and to keep those jobs engaging.

The realms in which we work are both complicated (predictable) and complex (unpredictable). Complicated realms, offer the certainty of expertise to determine outcomes. The complex realm, is the domain of uncertainty - unknown unknowns, where outcomes can't be predicted or solved using expertise alone. This is the domain of ‚Äòemergence‚Äô. To thrive in complexity we need to let go of the temptation to find a solution. Instead of leading from a place of ‚Äòprobability‚Äô (what we think will happen), we lead from a place of ‚Äòpossibility‚Äô (what could happen). Instead of leading from past experience, we lead with presence, knowing there is no definite destination to get to, only moment to moment direction that emerges from curiosity and the creative space of the collective. That means letting go of needing ourselves and others to ‚Äòbe right‚Äô, since there are no right solutions in complexity.  Thriving in complexity means letting go of our fear of failure and instead learning from it. Creating ‚Äòsafety zones‚Äô for people to make ‚Äòsafe-to-fail‚Äô bets. How ready are you, to lead in this context of uncertainty? If you‚Äôd rather thrive than just survive let‚Äôs have a conversation.
Book a 30-minute free discovery session here https://lnkd.in/gu_bKJw

Many professionals wonder what they can transition to doing as a second career, and teachers are no different. I'd asked myself many times what else I was qualified for and capable of doing based off of the many 'teacher skills' I have. I tried health/voluntary insurance sells, as I really wanted to help others, but wasn't the pushy kind of salesperson and starting your own business not only once, but twice after a move was too much for me. I wanted something I could work from one location, help others and enjoy where I work, thus my move to the HR field, plus teachers are well-versed at taking tests, so another one is no big deal! ;-)
